Qst.Quest: if a person (details supplied) in Dublin 1 who was awarded maintenance which is £12 less than the social welfare allowances of which she was previously in receipt (i) will be paid the difference and (ii) will be paid the full amount if her spouse fails to pay this maintenance; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: It is a condition for continued receipt of deserted wife's payment that a recipient continue to make reasonable efforts within the means available to her to seek maintenance from her husband if he is in a position to support her. As the husband of the person concerned is employed she was requested to provide evidence of her efforts to seek maintenance but to date has failed to do so.

MainHeading.P: If the level of maintenance is as described by the Deputy, the recipient would no longer be entitled to receive a desertion payment. There is no legal provision within social welfare legislation to pay the difference between a desertion payment and the maintenance received. Where a deserting spouse fails to honour a maintenance order, the deserted party should seek enforcement proceedings. The ongoing entitlement to deserted wife's payment is reviewed in the light of the outcome of such proceedings. The rules and procedures applicable to maintenance payments to deserted spouses are being reviewed in the context of provisions to pursue deserting spouses for contributions towards the cost of income maintenance payments provided to their families by the Department.

Qst.Quest: the present position regarding the case of a person (details supplied) in County Kerry who was in receipt of disability benefit and was considered capable of work by two medical referees and a deciding officer from his Department but who was not allowed resume work by the company's medical officer on the grounds of incapacity.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: Payment of disability benefit was disallowed to the person concerned from 5 October 1989 following an examination by a medical referee who considered him capable of work. He appealed against this decision and was examined by a different medical referee who also expressed the opinion that he was capable of work.

MainHeading.P: The case was then referred to an appeals officer who held an oral hearing on 28 February 1990. The person concerned attended the hearing alone although he was advised of his right to have his own doctor present in support of his appeal.

Having regard to all the facts available to him, the appeals officer decided that the person concerned was capable of work within the meaning of the Social Welfare Acts from 5 October 1989 and is not entitled to be paid disability benefit from that date.
The appeals officer's decision is final and conclusive and may only be altered in the light of new facts or fresh medical or other evidence.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Barrett Mr. M. Barrett
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the serious problem that exists in the Finglas and Ballymun areas of Dublin 11 in relation to stray animals; to the fact that none of the previous proposals made by him have materialised; and if he will take action in order to eliminate this problem.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: I am aware of the problem referred to and I have taken a number of measures to alleviate it.

A major part of the problem is in relation to the removal of stray animals to the pound. A four wheel drive jeep and a double horsebox have been purchased recently for the use of the Garda in the Dublin metropolitan area to enable them, from within their own resources, to transport wandering animals, particularly wandering horses, to the pound. The use of these vehicles by the Garda will supplement the activities of Dublin Corporation and county council who also of course, have a responsibility in this respect.

Several members of the force attached to the northern division of the Dublin metropolitan area, which includes the Finglas and Ballymun areas, are at present undergoing training in the handling of the new equipment which the Garda authorities expect to have operational within the next few days.

I have approved by ministerial order, with effect from 22 January 1990, significant increases in the pound fees which are imposed on owners when they come to retrieve animals found wandering (Statutory Instrument No. 4 of 1990).

In the case of horses, these charges have gone up from £18.40 to £23 per day. I intend to keep these charges under regular review. I should also point out that the owner will be required to defray the full cost of any expenses incurred in removing the animal to the pound before it is released.

The wandering animals problem is not confined to the north Dublin area although it is acknowledged to be most acute there. The Garda authorities are monitoring the situation closely and are keeping my Department informed of developments.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Second Level Education.

Qst.Quest: the subjects which must be taught in secondary schools; if she will outline the minimum range of subjects required to be taught; and if she will explain the status of: (a) home economics (b) physical education (c) woodwork (d) music and (e) career guidance, in the area of secondary education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Section IV (Rule Number 20 to 23) of the Rules and Programme for Secondary Schools contains the details on the school curriculum and courses of instruction. Rule 20 states:
The curriculum of a secondary school must include instruction in a syllabus approved by the Minister in the following subjects:—
A — Irish
B — English
C — History and Geography
D — Mathematics
E — Science; or a language other than Irish and English; or Commerce; or a subject of the Business Studies Group
F — Civics
Physical education should form part of the curriculum. The programme should be based on the approved syllabus and teaching hours should be registered on the school timetable.
The curriculum should also include provision for singing. The provision made for singing should be included in the school timetable.

Home economics and music are optional subjects on the approved course for both junior cycle and senior cycle pupils. Woodwork at junior cycle and construction studies, the corresponding subject at senior cycle, are optional subjects. Physical education is a non-examination subject for which there is a syllabus designed to cater for pupils following a full post-primary programme.

MainHeading.P: Career guidance may be provided in junior and senior cycles on certain conditions, the teacher to be in-quota or exquota depending on the size of the school.

Qst.Quest: her views on the situation that, while the children of the nation should be treated equally, the ability of well-off parents, whose children go to schools in middle class areas, to make voluntary contributions, give these children an advantage over children in poorer districts; if schools in disadvantaged areas, both primary and secondary, should be afforded an increased capitation grant to compensate for the inability of parents to make voluntary contributions as is the case at Our Lady of Mercy Secondary School, Mourne Road, Drimnagh, Dublin 12; and if reference to the statistics of unemployment levels of parents of children enrolled in these schools could act as the basis of positive discrimination.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The day-to-day running costs of national schools are met by the provision of State capitation grants and contributions from local sources. The capitation grant is not intended to meet operating costs in full. Each board of management is responsible, under the Rules for National Schools, for making arrangements for the collection of such funds locally, in supplement of the State grant, as will ensure that the school premises will be adequately heated and cleaned and kept in a proper decorative condition.

The capitation grant scheme is of general application and it was concluded, after an examination of the matter in 1985, that it would not be possible, within the existing resources available, to depart from the present system of school financing.

An increase in the capitation grant for national schools is being provided for in 1990. The standard rate of grant is being increased from £26.50 to £28.00 per pupil. Furthermore I have secured an increased allocation of £1.5 million for the support of national schools in disadvantaged areas in 1990.

Special provision for second level schools in disadvantaged areas has been made previously by way of additional teachers. Moreover, in accordance with the Programme for Government and the current Programme for National Recovery the Government hve decided that extra resources will be made available to provide additional teachers in specific disadvantaged areas. Appointments will be effective from the start of the 1990/91 school year. Officials of the Department are at present engaged in discussions with the interested parties on the question of criteria to be applied in determining disadvantaged areas.
I would also like to point out that the per capita grant for secondary schools generally has been increased from £140 to £150 with effect from 1 January, 1990.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Tallaght, Dublin, School Site.

Qst.Quest: if she will make arrangements to carry out repairs to the boundary fencing of the site for a second level school at Castleview, Tallaght, Dublin 24, which is in the ownership of her Department, as has been requested by many residents in the area who complain that the current state of the fencing is in a dangerous condition and its poor condition allows free access to the site in question which is being used for anti-social activities; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The site for the proposed second level school at Castleview, Tallaght, Dublin 24 has recently been inspected by my Department. Arrangements are being made to have the repairs to the fencing carried out as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Ashbourne, County Meath, School Project.

Qst.Quest: when tenders will be sought for a replacement Irish language school in Ashbourne, County Meath; and if she intends providing a general purpose room in the new school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The preparation of plans for the overall site layout for Gaelscoil na Cille, Cill Dhéaglain, Ashbourne, County Meath is in hands. The appointment of a quantity surveyor and structural engineer to prepare bills of quantities and structural drawings respectively is under consideration. The full tender documentation will be completed as soon as possible and the invitation of tenders will then arise for consideration.

My Department has agreed to the school's authorities' request to the use of a hall as a general purpose facility. It will not be possible to grant-aid the hall at this time, because priority must be given to the provision of essential classroom accommodation.

Qst.Quest: if she will outline her plans for the future of St. Clare's School, Harold's Cross, Dublin 6; and if this school is due to close in the near future.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The question of closure of St. Clare's national school is not under consideration in my Department at present.
I have no proposals at this time for a change in the status of the school from that previously sanctioned by my Department.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if she will lift the embargo on the appointment of school caretakers and school secretaries in those schools where the authorities are unable to obtain such personnel under the FÁS scheme.

Qst.hpid: Dr. D. Fitzpatrick Dr. D. Fitzpatrick
Qst.Quest: when it is proposed to allow schools which, through one reason or another, have lost secretaries to replace these secretaries.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 167 and 168 together.

In accordance with a Government decision in 1983 my Department's existing schemes for the employment of school caretakers and secretaries is being phased out as employees resign or retire. There is no other scheme operated under my Deartment for the employment of caretakers or secretaries.
The filling of non-teaching posts in schools continues to be subject to the overall policy obtaining in regard to staffing in the public service.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Flanagan Mr. Flanagan Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.asker: Mr. J. Bruton and Mr. Flanagan
Qst.Quest: if she will consider introducing provisions to cope with accidents occurring at schools including: (a) having an accident record book in each school similar to that in industry (b) giving teachers authority to call medical help for individual students without the necessity of consulting parents or guardians (c) giving teachers training in first aid (d) operating regular fire drills in schools and (e) issuing general guidelines to schools in relation to ways of coping with accidents occurring in school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The issues to which the Deputies refer are in the first instance matters for the authorities of individual schools. My Department has from time to time issued detailed fire safety documentation to schools and some years ago was involved in the preparation of general guidelines on first aid, which were produced by the Health Education Bureau and issued to schools.

I recently launched a report prepared by the Irish Red Cross on safety in schools. The booklet and posters accompanying the report will give teachers interesting ideas about safety in schools and will build an awareness in children of the importance of safety in the classroom and in the playground.

Qst.Quest: if she will list the new post-primary schools which are at present proceeding through the various stages; the stage of the planning process which each school is at; the date on which each school proceeded to that particular stage; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The present position in regard to building projects in second level schools is that each such project is being reviewed in the context of anticipated pupil enrolments in the catchment area for both the short and long-term. A decision in each case as to whether the project in question may be permitted to proceed to the next stage will be taken when the review is completed.
The compilation of the information requested by the Deputy would involve the deployment of staff from other more urgent work and would not be considered warranted in the circumstances mentioned.

Qst.Quest: the action which is being taken to ensure that Irish sport remains drug free.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The need for introducing measures to combat drug-taking in sport is recognised by the Government. Accordingly, procedures are in train for Ireland to sign the Anti-Doping Convention of the Council of Europe.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Askeaton (Limerick) Second Level Education Facilities.

Qst.Quest: if she will outline her proposals regarding the provision of a secondary school in Askeaton, County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The north central area of County Limerick is served by four post-primary schools, located at Askeaton, Foynes, Shanagolden and Pallaskenry. The combined enrolment in the school year 1989-90 was 830 pupils.

The question of how best to organise the provision of post-primary facilities in the area, in the long-term interest of all the pupils, has been the subject of discussions with the school authorities concerned.

In this context a number of important issues have to be addressed by the Department, i.e. the declining pupil potential as evidenced by the demographic trends, and, of course, the capital cost implications.
I hope to make a final decision in the matter following the outcome of these discussions which are on-going.

Qst.Quest: if she will outline her proposals regarding the provision of a community school in Rathkeale, County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: A decision was taken in 1983 by the then Minister, to approve the establishment of a community school in Rathkeale amalgamating the two existing post-primary schools — the vocational school and the Mercy secondary school.

The architectural planning of a building project for the new community school has been proceeding within my Department. In line with all major building projects the Rathkeale project is subject to review in the light of the most up-to-date statistical data available.
Any necessary decisions in relation to the Rathkeale project will be taken by me in the light of this review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Second Level School Projects.

Qst.Quest: when construction will commence for the second level schools sanctioned under the experimental design, finance and construct scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: These projects are under consideration in my Department and accordingly, I am not in a position at this stage to say when construction work will commence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Feabhsúcháin do Ghairmscoil i gContae na Gaillimhe.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: an bhfuil cinneadh dearfa déanta aici airgead a chur ar fáil chun na feabhsúcháin atá riachtanach agus práinneach ag gairmscoil Cholm Cille in Indreabhán a thosú; agus cathain a thosóidh an obair ar an scoil.

Speaker.hpid: Aire Oideachais (Mrs. O'Rourke) Aire Oideachais (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: Cosúil le gach tionscnamh tógala do scoileanna atá a phleanáil faoi láthair, tá cás Ghairmscoil Cholm Cille a athbhreithniú i gcomhthéacs líon na ndaltaí is féidir a bheith ag súil leis sa cheantar go gearrthéarmach agus go fadthéarmach. Chomh luath is a bheidh an t-athbhreithniú críochnaithe, tiocfar ar bhreith maidir le hiarratas togála na scoile.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dublin School Post Application.

Qst.Quest: if she has received a request from Archbishop McQuaid senior national shcool, County Dublin, for the appointment of a remedial teacher; and if she will agree to the request.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Each application for the services of a remedial teacher is considered on its merits and posts are allocated in accordance with priority of need. In assessing the need my Department has regard to the professional advice of its inspectorate.

I have sanctioned during 1989/90 30 additional remedial teachers in primary schools. The application in question was unsuccessful on this occasion. I will, however, be keeping the appointment of further remedial teachers in primary schools under review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Substitute Primary Teachers.

Qst.Quest: if she will give an estimate of the number of substitute primary teachers in the primary school system; the basis on which these teachers are paid; if she will outline their conditions of employment; and if she has any plans to improve their situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: It is estimated that the total number of substitute primary teachers is in the region of 3,400, of whom, on any one day, 815, on average, are serving.

Applications for payment in respect of the employment of substitutes by school boards of management are made to my Department by the chairpersons of the boards. Payment, less the appropriate rate of PRSI, is made by my Department to the chairpersons who, in turn, recoup the teachers.

MainHeading.P: Substitute teachers are employed in respect of absences by full-time teachers on (a) paid sick leave, (b) paid maternity leave, (c) jury service and (d) official courses. The daily rates of payment are £38 (trained) and £33.57 (untrained).

My Department are in regular discussion with all the teachers' associations with regard to their conditions of employment. Currently, a claim on behalf of substitute teachers in relation to pay rates is the subject of arbitration hearings.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Athlone, Westmeath, Sports Centre Project.

Qst.Quest: the allocation from national lottery funds for the Regional Sports Centre in Athlone, County Westmeath; if an architect has been appointed for the project; and when work will commence on the project.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Athlone has been designated by Government as the location for a regional sports centre with a maximum capital grant of £1.5 million from the national lottery.

Discussions between my Department and the local authority are at an advanced stage with regard to the facilities to be provided and the arrangements to be made for the design and construction of the centre.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Waterford Schools Application.

Qst.Quest: when she first received a request for the appointment of a remedial teacher to serve Ballyduff and Tallow national schools, County Waterford, the reason an appointment has not been sanctioned; and if she will give a commitment to sanction this post in the near future.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: An application for a remedial teacher to serve the schools in question was received in 1984.

MainHeading.P: Remedial teaching posts are allocated in accordance with priority of need of applicant schools as determined by my Department and not on the basis of date of application. The schools in question have not to date qualified for a remedial teacher on the basis of priority of need.
I have sanctioned during 1989/90 30 additional remedial teachers in primary schools and will be keeping the appointment of further remedial teachers under review.

Qst.Quest: if he intends to respond to a recent report (details supplied) concerning the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: I have received a copy of the report to which the Deputy refers and I have noted its contents. I do not propose to respond to the report at this time.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Kerry County Airport Project.

Qst.Quest: if further additional funds will be made available from EC Structural Funds towards the costs of major extensions to Kerry County Airport.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: Following a consultancy study, commissioned by Kerry County Airport plc., for the future development of the airport, the board submitted a proposal for its further development to my Department. The proposal is under consideration in the context of the operational programme for roads and other transport infrastructure which is being prepared for EC Structural Funds assistance.
